prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NGC4649: dense gas and RRL kinematics
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Survey of kinematics of dense gas tracers and RRLs. The lines covered are: Dense gas tracers: CS J:7-6 HCN J:4-3 HCO+ J:4-3 (partial coverage) HC18O+ J:4-3 added as bonus
RRL: H(26)alpha H(40)delta (partial coverage; added as bouns)
Three of the SPWs are slightly offset to avoid overlaps.
Unfortunately the J:4-3 line of CO and its isopotomers do not fit in this frequency setting.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Given that these are pilot observations at very high spatial resolution we would like to optimize SNR, and thus choose TDM mode. The resulting velocity resolution of about 25km/s (and thus line centering to a fraction of this depending on SNR) will still allow sufficient spectral resolution for our science goals. Total line widths are expected to be less than 500km/s and thus easily fit within the full baseband.

We ideally require 0.1 to 0.05arcsec resolution (equivalent to HST-STIS) for full constraints on black hole masses and other science goals. However, these are the highest resolution submm maps attempted on the proposed sources and thus the signal per spatial resolution element is unsure. To keep within realistic integration times for this pilot survey of a sample, we request 0.1 to 0.15 arcsec resolution. This is sufficient to address our immediate science goals. At these spatial and spectral resolutions the gas will present significant rotation/inflow/outflow motions and we do not expect angular scales of greater than 4" in any given spectral channel. Larger scale continuum emission may be resolved out, but that is not criticalt to our science goal.

Our sample consists of local (distances 0.8 to 28Mpc) bright and massive galaxies, with single dish observations showing CO J:1-0 fluxes of 50 to hundreds of K km/s in the central 30arcsec of their nuclei. ALMA's previous experience with galaxies similar to those in our sample (eg. NGC1097, NGC1068, M87 etc., plus four galaxies from Nagar's cycle 1 project: NGC1667, NGC1566, NGC1386 and NGC7213) show that strong detections of dense gas tracers are obtained in less than 30min integrations in Cycles 0 to 2. Further, the nuclear gas appears to be typically clumpy, and on small scales. To balance depth vs. number of targets and stay within a reasonable amount of time we target a uniform rms sentitivity of 0.4mJy per beam in a 25km/s channel, significantly deeper than previous such observtions. Velocity averaging will be used in some galaxies to increase signal to noise ratios when neccessary.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Given that these are pilot observations at very high spatial resolution we would like to optimize SNR, and thus choose TDM mode. The resulting velocity resolution of about 25km/s (and thus line centering to a fraction of this depending on SNR) will still allow sufficient spectral resolution for our science goals. Total line widths are expected to be less than 500km/s and thus easily fit within the full baseband.

We ideally require 0.1 to 0.05arcsec resolution (equivalent to HST-STIS) for full constraints on black hole masses and other science goals. However, these are the highest resolution submm maps attempted on the proposed sources and thus the signal per spatial resolution element is unsure. To keep within realistic integration times for this pilot survey of a sample, we request 0.1 to 0.15 arcsec resolution. This is sufficient to address our immediate science goals. At these spatial and spectral resolutions the gas will present significant rotation/inflow/outflow motions and we do not expect angular scales of greater than 4" in any given spectral channel. Larger scale continuum emission may be resolved out, but that is not criticalt to our science goal.

Our sample consists of local (distances 0.8 to 28Mpc) bright and massive galaxies, with single dish observations showing CO J:1-0 fluxes of 50 to hundreds of K km/s in the central 30arcsec of their nuclei. ALMA's previous experience with galaxies similar to those in our sample (eg. NGC1097, NGC1068, M87 etc., plus four galaxies from Nagar's cycle 1 project: NGC1667, NGC1566, NGC1386 and NGC7213) show that strong detections of dense gas tracers are obtained in less than 30min integrations in Cycles 0 to 2. Further, the nuclear gas appears to be typically clumpy, and on small scales. To balance depth vs. number of targets and stay within a reasonable amount of time we target a uniform rms sentitivity of 0.4mJy per beam in a 25km/s channel, significantly deeper than previous such observtions. Velocity averaging will be used in some galaxies to increase signal to noise ratios when neccessary.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Despite it now being well established that nearly all galaxies have a central black hole whose mass scales with the host galaxy properties, we do not have a complete understanding of the physics at work. In particular, we do not know whether black holes, or galaxies, are the driving the scaling relations. Although we know that the M-sigma and M-L relations are incompatible in the largest galaxies, we do not know which is wrong. We are now at the limits of what can be learned with ~80 data points with substantial measurement uncertainties, and urgently require additional precision data. ALMA is capable of measuring black hole masses at high precision for a large number of sources. Here, we propose observations of a modest pilot sample of nearby galaxies in order to: (1) Measure black hole masses in 3 new sources with large angular spheres of influence, (2) measure the central parsec gas dynamics in most or all 8 sources allowing us to better understand the systematics in molecular and radio recombination line (RRL) black hole mass measurements, and (3) determine suitability for all sources for event horizon shadow resolution with the Event Horizon Telescope.
